Storr, C.B., Assistant Secretary.Captain L. F. Burgis, Assistant Secretary.Mr. G. M. Evans, Assistant Secretary.Printed for the War Cabinet. August .1919. labour Situation. 1 -The. Prime -Minister -stated. -that- he. would like to have a discussion in the Cabinet on the Labour situation, so that he. should be able to make a reference to it in his statement on the adjournment. He had had one or two conversations with theMinister of Labour, and there were a few things, such as profit-sharing, unemployment, and the question of organising the tradesfor the purpose of some sort of insurance benefit on a contributory basis, which he ought to mention. Lie enquired whether there wasanything which the Government ought to do with regard to theLabour question.The Minister of Labour said that his Department were working-out an insurance scheme on a contributory basis. He thought theGovernment "would have to introduce something of this kind iuthe autumn, in view of the possibility of considerable unemploy-ment during the*winter.It was agreed that the War Cabinet should meet at 6 p.m. thesame evening, in order to discuss the Labour situation.Archangel. 2. The Secretary of State for War informed the War Cabinetthat our forces in North Russia had won a considerable victory onthe Dvina front. In addition to routing the enemy, we had captured 2,000 prisoners, including most of his officers, and morethan half of the enemy's artillery.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W. 1,August 14, 1919.o
